bibl.note: This document, entitled "Thrilling Narrative. How The Judgement of Heaven fell on the Indians who wounded Rev'd Joseph Brown in 1794," was written to Colonel A. W. Putman on March 30, 1858 by Reverend Joseph Brown. In this narrative Brown details the events surrounding his return trip from Knoxville to Nashville. It appears that he was informed by a Cherokee trader that there was a large body of Indians waiting to do harm on the direct route, so he was advised to return through Kentucky. Accepting this advice, Brown and travel partners, William Hayes, a Negro woman, Ross, Friley, and others set out only to be ambushed along the way by Indians. During the attack Brown was wounded in the shoulder although they escaped. He stayed with a Dutch man for two nights and then with a brother-in-law, who was a doctor, of Ross's for six weeks, until he healed well enough to travel home. Later, Brown was informed by another trader that the same party of Indians had rode into East Tennessee to take prisoners of women and children and if Brown and others wanted to free the prisoners he would show them where they were. Brown set out with a group of white men to seek revenge on the Indians. When they located them they noticed that the Indians were wearing white men's clothing and, satisfied that these were the guilty Indians, they decided to lay in wait to ambush them in the morning fearing that the prisoners would be killed if they acted too quickly. The Indians were all killed the next day and the white men found a little girl who had hid for three days. Brown submitted this account with the intent that it would be published or returned. It was, in fact, published in the "Banner of Peace" August 5, 1858.

yours of the 2nd
Inst Came to hand last night from
pleasant Grove
Pleasant Grove never was my Post office tho I lived handey to it for maney years but Pulaskie Giles County is now my post office and Relative to your Enquiry
General A. Jackson was not on the Nickajack Campain but if My Memory Serves me he at that time had somthing to do in the Contractor busines for his Brother in law
Mr Samuel Donnelson Came to our camp a day or two before we started and
Wm. Reed of
sumner County was there and neather of them had Ever been beat at a foot race and Donnelson Observed that he was in bad fix to Run for he had been gatherng
Beevers the day before but still he was willing to Run to gratify The Company and did Run and was beat five or six feet, but
Sandey Donnelson Did gow and Was Wounded at Nickajack a younger Brother so I know that Jackson and the Donnelsons done all they could for The protection of the Countrey, Altho I presum
Doct Ramsay had been WRongley informed on that Subject. and as to Rele
icts of the war I now have none. I had an Elegant Sword but I gave it to one of my Grand sons and it is gone to Texas or the society should have it

if I live to the 2nd day of August next I shall be Eighty six years old, so I hope you l Excuse my Enterlining
c but Mrs Fogg has attempted to give a history of the mercey of God, to so unprofitable a mortal as I have Ever been to society there is one neaver been penned,
is one as strong as that has been penned.

I went to East Tennessee on Buisnes in the winter of 1793 and on My Return got in company with
Col Robert Hayn
se a Brother in law of General Jackson and When we got to Knoxville , the night before a Trader and William Blunt
, then Governor, or Governor, Sevear
Sevier
, I do not
know which was Governor of the Terretory at that time; this Cherrokee Trador informed them that a large Bodey of Indians was a boute
start (paper is torn at end of word) to way lay the tras ce Comeing to
Nashvill and we had better turn and Come by
Kai entuckey
. we done so and the 2nd night we got in three miles of the last house, and I had a Negro Woman a long and we Concluded not to Eat BreaKfast to we Would go there and then not stop to night; but when we Went to start, the horse the Negro Rode was badly [foundered, a gentlman
a long said, if I would bleed him at the Edge of the hair round his feet he would be well in a mile or two I requested him to do it for me, he attempted to do so but the horse was
was verry wild and Jirked up his foot and the Knife went into the artery in the front of his foot and I made the woman ride my horse and I walked and Drove the foundered one to the last house. he Bled all the way and while the Company was Eating I got some cobwebs and held on it, and stoped the blood we then started up Clinch Mounten
road but before we got halfway up
the mounten it broke to Bleeding as fast as Ever and I Knew I should lose my horse if I went on.] I observed to
Col Hayse that I woul be glad he would take charge of the Negro woman as I hade to stop with my horse and She had provison a nough to do her to
Nashvel but he would have to buy some corn for the horse in
Kaintuckey
. he said he wou ld do so Chearfuly for my Brother
William had saved his life two years before, at
Emreys River
provably 12 miles from Kingston, East Tennessee, a large Bodey of Indians fired on them a boute day brak ,
as
the were a waking out of sleep. they Indians Rushed on them, it was a of a mile to Emreys River they Ran to the River. my Brother was shot in the back of his Right hand and the Ball Came out at his WRist but he got his clothing off and tied them with his hand kerchief to a chunk, but not being tied good and the Riffeling of the water the hankerchief came lo ose and at that instant
Col. Haysewas a sinking gust before him he caught his shirt in his teeth and he being a good swimmer gave his Chunk to Hayse and by that means both lives were saved, tho my Brother had lost three fine horses and all his money and clothing but his shirt.
but it was only 12 or 15 miles to the settelment .

after Hayse give the a bove information the Company started and I stayed with my horse and held the wound to
till it began to swell. then I led him Back to the fort and stayed there one wea ek to my horse got well and the Post Rider Thomas Ross and
Col Friley came a long and as they lived in
Kaintucky I conclude
if they could gow safe I could, accordinly we started the next Morning and went on all day veary well but the 2nd day a bout two a Clock on the East side of
littel Sorrel River we ware ere fired on by a partey of Indians We Dashed forward a bout 150 yards to the River it did not swim (inkblot) us at the ford. the Roade led up the River tho a littel distance from the River and in a bout
the
a of mile it came near the Road a gain, and at that plase a littel Harricn Hurricane had cros sed the Roade the summer before but the guard that went threw to protect the Traveller had the cut the limbs of the fallen trees so that the pack horses could git a long,
Rosses
horse creature could out Run my horse I think he was a rod a head of me.
gust as we Enterd the fallen timber an Indian from behind a tree fired at him and I suppose shot his horsecreture thro the Ear for she was shot threw the Ear she Wheealed back and at they fired on Ross me,
Friley said ther was twenty or thirty guns fired at us two, for Friley was forty yards behind but our horse scaring at the screaming of the Indians and guns and dodging they mised us boath . we Dashed back and met
Frily and we all Came in a breast to a large fallen tree and I was on theleft and Ross in the middel and as
Rosses mare as charged the log her four feet went in to ground so she fel on her Brast , and then on her side and he went over her head and his gun fell out of his hand he sprand g to his gun and looked at his mare and I suppose he thought she was killed for I Expected mine to fall Evry minuite the kept missing me so much and
that was the last I seen of him I then Reiend my horse to pas the Bend of the Rive
Friley hollerred at me not to gow there for he said when they fired on Ross and me in the Hurricane he seen the trees all lined with Indians betwean me and the River I then made for the River and when I came to it
it was a high caving bank I turned down the River but it got no better four or five feet to the watter.
Friley Hollorred to me that he was wounded, and for me to charge my horse down the bank or they would have us I answerd him that I was wounded also and turned my horse toward the River. he sailed of as tho it was level ground the first plunge took me Round the
middel in swimming watter. he then took Down the River with me and unc I could do I could not turn him. at length I hit him with my left hand on the side of his head and that turned him as my Right arm fel dead when the Ball Struck me and I would have left him in River but I was fearful that I could not swim out with one hand having my over Coat on and I thought the horse was shot and dying but I thougt I would trey to mak him Carrey me to the shore and when he got to the bank it was slate bank he got a boute half way up the the bank. He got a boute
half way up the the bank and fel and I thot he was dead and sprung off him and shoved my over Coat off the point of my shoalder to Run and at that moment I seen aw
Rosses mare Nearing the bank. I caught my coat again and pulled it up and made for
Rosses mare, and as she pased me I got hold of the Bridal le. it was a mong her feet tho not tangled I put it over her head and sprung on her and Came off on her
and as I Raised the Bank I seen aw
Friley a gowing over the hill more than a hundred yards a head Altho he went after me into the river and it Did not Swim him, and he had a low bank to rise. if my horse would have gone straight a Cross he would have the same low Bank but as I mounted
Roses
mare I started the Course I seen aw
Frily
a gowing after going fiftey or sixtey yards I look Round to see if I could see aney of theIdians that first fired on me on that side of the Rive and dscovered my own horse Right at heals my heaeels. I checked my mare a moment to he pased me and I heard the scream after him and turned him the way I seen Frileygow and directly struck his trail it was post oak land and the Indians had Burnt the laves of the ground his mare had thrown up the White clay as he Run so I could see his trail for thirtey yards a head I could see the Blood on Bushes where he pased and in a bout the of a mile I over took him
he had stoped in a
littel Sunk plas ce, he said he was so sick he would be obliged to git down. I oberved to him if you git down you neaver will git up again for the Indian will be hear in les than five minutes and besides that your horse is shot in his they ighs he may not Carrey you twenty minutes, shove him as long as you Can. he then observed, go a head , and I will try to keep up I went of East probably a mile and turned north and struck the River a gain at som
Buffelow licks which I was informed after I got in the settelment was five miles from the ford where I had cosed, the River there was a small stream
not belley Deep on our horses and after I had crosed I seen my horse had stoped to eat some kain cane that was on the bank I then turned back and caught my own horse he had lost the rains reins of my Bridel le. I then pulled the Bridel le off
Rosses mare and put it on my own horse and Drove the mare threw the River and Requested
friley to Drive her after me he said he was so sick he could not but she would follow us, she had the mail on and his Blanket sircingeled on Just as he left her I went on a westerly course and in les than a mile we struck the Rode
Friley was so deranged he wanted to take the Rong end of the Rode I informed him that I would not keep the Rode any further I Enquired of him the Cours to the settelment of
Kaintuckey as I had neaver been there he said it was a but a sun set course if I know which way (hole in page) that was a beutiful Clear day and at that plase the Rode was a gowing right north I went right a cros the Rode took up a long hill and gust as I got to the top of the hill I struck a path leading westerly which I thought was a Buffelow path leading to a lick and from there I could git a path leading almost aney course for miles but after I had followed it,
povibelly half a mile it began to give out and supposed the main path was to the Right and took down a point of the Ridge and had not gone more than of a mil before I seen a fresh parsel of logs puled up by the side of a big log I conclude som Indian had died and the had coverd him up there and I would gow and see but when I got there I got down and seen it was a White man. I then looked
over on the North side of the hill and seen where the Idians had emptied the Fether Beds of a Company they had defeated at that veary plase the Monday weak before, and there was a man in that Company a Running of with a nother mans wife and the woman had her littel dauter
a bout seaven years Oald a Riding behind her and when the Indians fired on them the horse threw the woman and littel girl and the man sprang of his horse gathered the woman and threw her on his own horse and Jumped on behind her and left the littel girl a laying there and the Indians took her, the Mans Nam was Drake and the woman the wife of Webb Nance

Friley said to me we had better take the road as we were so near it for there was a duch man three or four miles from there that had a good Block house and a good horse pen near the Doors and a number of guns dogs we then made for the Rode and went as fast as our horses Could Carrey us I kep
hart hole to I got in a mile of the house and was verey sick the Duch man was kind took my horse and put him in his pen and dresed my wound found a peas of the socket Bone of my shoalder in my shirt and put some shugar and whiskey to my wound and give me a Deer skin to lay down on
which I Occopyed for two nights and a day with a high feaver, and seaverl times in the day the informed me the Believed my hors would die as we had fed our horses with the Corn the had been Carreying on their backs Just before the Indians fired on us and my horse was Just giting over a founder, and straing him for ten or twelve miles founderd him over again but he was the only one man or beast in the Company but was killed wound or taken as Friley lost one of his that he had a pack on and his mare that was shot in the
they proved to be a slight wound and his wound was a bove and below his Elbo only in the flesh but he Bled so much that he was veary sick to we got near the Rode whare
Drak was Defeated

the second night a boute midnight a Company of three men and two wemen Came threw after us and had stoped at
littel Sorrel River to Camp as it was gitting Dark and found poor Ross striped naked and his head cut off and that alarmed them the mounted thier horses and Cam 12 miles to where I was the next morning my feaver had subsided and my horse had got up I pled with thos theavs as I learned afterward that was their Carrcter in Georgia and ware then a Rung a way , to pack my horse as he was so stiff and let me Rideone of their pack horses but the Refused (inkblot)and said I could
not gow I Replyed there was no could not with me I mus gow whare I could git medical aid and noureshment and directed the Dutch man to put my saddel on my own horse that the Road was a free for me as aney other person but I did not gow ove a quarter of a mile before I discoverd
Rosses mare a gain but she had lost her mail and sadel I Rode Round her and one of those men did help me to catch her and put on my saddel on her and I got on her she was a delightfule Riding Animal and it was Caled forty miles to the Crab Orcherd the first settelment and we goot thare before dark but I was veary much Exausted and thare was a Doctor a Brother in law of
Rosses that lived in sixty or Eighty yard of the fort I of course went to the Docters and the treated me with grate deal of kindness and tenderness for six weaks before I felt abel to start home and the Docter would not suffer me to Eat meet but kep me on swetned vinnagar and watter and bread as it was in March and the Cows genraley had their Calves with them in the Cain but
Col Wm Whitley lived in three miles and in about three weaks I got so I could Ride and I went to
Whiteys Every other day to git me a cup of Buttermilk they ware veary kind to me and the next summer Come a year
Col Whitley Came to
Nashvile
with a large Company of men to gow with Major Orr of East Tennessee and the Volenters around to gow from
Nashvile
to to take the Town of
Necajack
whare I had been a prisner by the Cherrokes six years before of Course I went a long
all tho the wound was still a Runing in boath sides and peases of bone kep comeing out for two years and at that time there was a hole Clean threw my shoalder and on that Campain a Nefew of
Col Whitley give me information of the (inkblot) Judgment of Heaven on the veary Indians that wounded me a Trader had Just come in from the Norther Indians I who said thare ware sixty from one Town that Cam out to way lay the Rode from
Kaintuck to East Tennessee the winter and spring befor and after the had defeated Differnt famely on the Rode the toke a fort on
slate River and took prisners and was followed by a Companey for some distance and som stoney ground the Indians had scatterd so that thear trail could not be followed the Company Returned and Simon Kenton who had been a prisner by the Indians then Commande a Company Observed he thought that he knew what Indians the ware from the Course they ware a gowing and if his men would gow with him he would follow them his men ware willing to gow and they started and got to whare the others turned back but he went the Course he supposed the Indians did gow and gust before night he struck a large trail and followed to he found he was near them he then stoped his men and went on himself to he come to their camp and found they had more camps then he had men he then
informed his men of their dainger and thought the had better git as fare back as possibel that night for the Indians would see their trail in the morning and follow them then the turned for home and gust before day he Came in sight of a fire he stoped his men and went and Exmined the Camp and seen
whare thare was parsel of peopel that was covered with white peoples clothing he then went back and informed his men that the ware the verey Indians the ware a hunting but it would not do to fire on them if the did the Indians would Tomhawk the prisners but the must git as nigh as the could and lay still to it was light a nough to see to shoot a man ten steps and then Run upon them with their Tom hak and then as the run shoot them and by that means they would save the prisnors , and the done so and they thought the had killed all of them and thare they got the mail that I left on
Roses mare and the prisners that was taken when
Mr. McFarlin was defeated the next Tuesday after I was Defeated and and the prisners that was taken when they took the Fort so that we knew it was the same Indians that had done all the mischief the Trader said thare was one onley got back out of sixtey that had started from That Town I will now give a relation of
McFarlen s Defeat the next Tuesday after I was defeated they ware
North Carolinians nine men and several wemen and and children and as
McFarlen was a
East Tenneseyan
the requested him to command them while in Wildernes he agreed to do so and had pased whare I was Defeated and near whare
drake was defeated and he seen a small Rock by the side of saplin on a Bank
and he said he thought that had not grew thare glanced his Eyes Closely on it and
Discoverd the musel of the Indian gun on the top of the Rock he cried Indians unc and sprung of his horse and Drew his sight to split the fellows head as soon as he Raised it but he supposed the fello seen him between the Rock and the saplin and sprang of to Come unc Round him he Ran Even with the fellow forty or fiftey yards and a bout forty yards a part and he seen the fellow was a bout stoping and he thought he could out shoot any Indian but the Indian gun fired first and shot threw
McFarlin Clothing on one side but he kiled the Indian he gumped behind a tree and loaded again gust at that time a nother Indian came Runing Round and he Run with him and Run forty or fifty steps and he the fellow was a but stoping and he still thought he Could out shote aney Indian but that fellows gun fired Rather first and shot threw McFarlin clothing on the other side but but he
Droped him he then got behind a nother tree and loaded again and a third fellow Came Round and he looked like a whit man or a veary fair half breed and
Mc and him had a semilar Race and as the fellow stoped the Boath fired and the Fellow shot of
Mc Charger and threw his shot pouch strap but
Mc
Droped him
Mc loaded and no others Came he then Ran back and he Could see but one of his men and he was a quarter of mile of and a Crowd of Indians had taken the wemen he said he then thought it was not worth whale to throw away his life he then left four of his men Dead on the ground and the fifth one dead by my side of his wound a company went to Berrey the dad with McFarlin and before the got to the
plase they seen a pack horse standing some distance from the Rode the Dashed out
and thare was a littel girl laying near him a sleep some of them said thare was one littel girl dead but then Comeing wakened (inkblot) her she look up and smiled to see the white men and thare
was hardley a man but shed tears the pack horse Run of with her in the of the fight and had thare got his Bridel fastend to again and had been near three days
Mc went on to the Battel ground and showed whare he stood and whare the Indians stood stood and thare was the Blood whare the fellows lay but the Indians had taken them away and a bout two hundred yards off in a tree top the last man man he shot was coverd and he was a white man and by finding the pack and littel girl the went back a long the Rode and found the track of Nances littel daughter that was taken when Drake was Defeated and the followed it by whare I was Defeated and it was called twelve miles from thare to
big Sorrel River and it was a Deep boald stream provibely forty yards yards wide the followed her thare and seen she had went down to the watter and Came up again and the went up and down the River in search of her at length the found her a bout three fourth of a mile from the ford down the River she was a perty littel girl with red hair and she said the Indins went Every day to watch the Road, and thare was three white men with them and one day the had been a shoting at the Road and Came back a grate while before night and only too of the white men came back and one of the Indians had a veary sore leg, and the Cried that Eavning veary much and the next morning the Cried a gain
and then started and Came back the same way the went to the Cam near the plase she was taken and in a few days the began to shoot at the again and the Indians that was at the Camp with her hopped and was mighty glad and all Run of to the Rode and left her by herself and she said she thought she would gow to unc hazel patch for she kew she had only pased the hazel patch a littel when she was taken by the Indians but she took the Rong end of the Rode and said she gather leaves Every night to the side of a log and lay in them and she had been near three days that she had Eat nothing when she was found and all the other children that was brought in was Frost bitten but her I am Now done with the Narative and as Mrs Fog
found me with one of her Books and will have the foreging publised in the history
Jo Brown as a second adition I wil take a Dozen or tw of them if I am alive the facts Contained in the history are Correct Exsept
Buckhana Fort the history says 14 miles from
Nashvile when it is only a bout 4 miles if the (damaged document) the above cannot be publised in a 2nd Edition of the history of
Jo Brown by Mrs Fogg or the Editor of the Banner of Peace or on the Methodists Editor you will pleas Return it by mail to me Pulaskie Giles Cty
